newsitem.title: USA: Microware enters pact with Corel, eyes other deals.
newsitem.headline: Microware enters pact with Corel, eyes other deals.

text.p: Microware Systems Corp's pact with Corel Corp is but the first of several alliances the firm hopes to make for its OS-9 real-time operating system this fall, the company said.

"There's a lot of activity in our business," said Ken Kaplan, Microware's chief executive. "I think you will see a series of announcements, both from us and our customers, continuing through the fall."
Real-time operating systems are slimmed down versions of full-scale software operating systems that can be used to run consumer electronics devices or small handheld computers.

On Thursday, Microware said Corel will use OS-9 as the platform for products using Corel's Java-based programming language, including Corel's business software suite composed of Wordperfect and the spreadsheet Quatrro Pro.
The Corel deal also allows Microware, whose OS-9 package will enable users of devices like handheld terminals that access the internet, to license Corel's Office software to its customers.

"Offering technology like the Corel Office for Java means that people...can access the same documents and databases while they are on the road, or even through a TV set potentially, that they can through their desktop today," Kaplan said.
He added that other deals are in the works.
"It's pretty well known that IBM is basing their wireless internet products on our operating system," he said, though no products have been officially announced.
The OS-9 operating system is expected to draw stiff competition from giants like Microsoft Corp and Apple Computer Inc for the non-desktop PC market.
Up to 22 million of these appliances, such as personal digital assistants, could be in use by the year 2000, according to a study by International Data Corp.
